Award.AwardTitle: Biology Opportunities and Scholarships for Success (BOSS) Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of West Alabama (UWA) Biology Opportunities and Scholarships for Success (BOSS) is supporting 16 undergraduates majoring in either Biology or Environmental Sciences who demonstrate academic potential, motivation for STEM, and financial need. Nearly half of the University's students (46%) are from six western Alabama counties, four of which are among the 20 poorest counties in the nation. The majority of UWA students are affiliated with underrepresented groups including women, ethnic minorities, and first-generation students. With a large population of under-served students in its targeted service area, UWA is distinctively set to address the needs of first-generation and low-income students.

The guiding objective of the BOSS program is to increase student retention through degree achievement by providing comprehensive educational opportunities so that the S-STEM scholars can reach their full academic potential. The program helps to increase the number of successful biological and environmental sciences graduates joining the workforce or graduate schools by providing career exploration and professional development opportunities. UWA also offers scholars a wide range of supportive services, including counseling services, focused student advising, and tutoring. The evaluation of student scholars involves an Individualized Success Plan (ISP) to assess every participant through ongoing evaluations pertinent to the student's success. Outcome data include academic progress reports, internship participation, professional presentations, and other professional networking activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biology Opportunities and Scholarships for Success (BOSS) was a major contributing factor in increasing the enrollment of talented undergraduate students in the biological and environmental sciences at the University of West Alabama (UWA) by at least 28% prior to the project. In addition, the NSF financial support and the comprehensive academic support provided to scholarship recipients led to increase retention and graduate rates. Overall, mostly all scholarship recipients have joined a graduate program in STEM or obtained a career locally.

Intellectual Merit: The focus of BOSS on fostering undergraduate research as a mechanism to drive inquiry-based instruction has been a critical element in a sea of changes in the Department of Biological and Environmental Sciences at UWA.  Undergraduate research, once a rarity in the Department and in the University as a whole, is now the norm.  The UWA Undergraduate Research Symposium, which began in 2012 with twelve participants, now routinely draws in excess of 75 entries. Many UWA students are now involved in authentic and original research that leads to presentations in a wide range of regional and international conferences. As a result, several BOSS scholars have also published articles in peer-reviewed journals. One former student, when asked to reflect on her experience as a BOSS scholar said, "Being a part of the BOSS program was incredibly rewarding. I was able to do research and develop closer relationships with students and faculty. Having the opportunity to do research helped me more than I realized at the time. I am currently pursuing a doctor of pharmacy and a master of public health, and everyone is incredibly impressed with my research background and the fact that I was able to create a poster and present at a research symposium."

The focus on providing student-driven research opportunities has reinvigorated faculty scholarship, and the pursuit of external funding has significantly increased within the department. In addition to research, BOSS has stimulated our undergraduate students to actively pursue a wide range of internships, which have further enhanced their academic experience and enlarged their professional network.  As a result, the number of UWA students obtaining summer internships has quadrupled when compared to the pre-BOSS culture. Finally, the BOSS program has improved both retention and graduation rates of biology majors, as well as enhanced the ability of those students to successfully compete for and transition into graduate/professional schools or the workplace. Ninety percent of the BOSS scholars graduated with a BS degree or Master's degree, and about 85% are pursuing a career or post graduate program in STEM related fields. Without doubt, conducting and presenting undergraduate research, participating in career building workshops, along with close advising and mentoring helped create a supportive community among Boss Scholars and faculty, which we feel was instrumental in improving student retention and success.

Broader Impact: The project has a broad impact in communities across west Alabama, east Mississippi and beyond by providing a hands-on, personal and goal-oriented educational experience for a group of highly skilled and capable high school graduates. Without NSF support in the form of scholarships, many of these talented students would have most assuredly attended college at other institutions, and by doing so, they would have not received the relevant confidence-building experiences that made them competitive for entry into graduate/professional school and the work force within their own communities. One BOSS scholar remarked, "The BOSS program has opened doors for me in my professional life. I am indebted to the program because they provided a long-lasting foundation for my future by providing mentorship with fellow students who were upperclassmen that had experience and were able to help others out by sharing those experiences."

It is apparent that BOSS has changed the culture of UWA's STEM undergraduate program, and has had a lasting impact on the local communities.  Although we supported 16 BOSS Scholars financially, over 20 non-BOSS STEM undergraduates became actively engaged in research opportunities, participated in career/resume/interviewing workshops along with the BOSS cohorts. In addition, BOSS scholars actively participated in recurring community outreach science activities effectively reaching nearly 1000 K-12 underprivileged students from the surrounding area. As a result, some of these former K-12 students are now pursuing degrees at various colleges and universities including UWA.

The outcome report reflect that this project has made considerable progress in meeting its goals, and majority of students are continuing in STEM careers and pursuing graduate school in related field.
